items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels on the river Avon are stable but remain high. Flooding is still expected to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. 

Further showers are forecast on Tuesday but are not expected to cause any further flooding. 

We are clearing debris from weed screens and monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Please avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and keep up to date with the weather forecast for your area. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

 This message will be updated by 11:00am on Sunday 02/02/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are high at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. The next high tides at Torksey will be at 11:30 today 01/02/2025 and 23:30 today 01/02/25. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
We expect river levels to remain high until 04/02/25. We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 01/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of rainfall associated with Storm Herminia. 
 
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.

No further significant rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
 
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated this evening, 01/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but stable on the River Churn.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25). The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are slowly falling on the River Cherwell between Lower Heyford and Oxford as a result of recent rainfall. However, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue, particularly in areas closest to the river around Thrupp, Kidlington and Shipton-on-Cherwell. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are stable on the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today (01/02/25), especially in areas close to the river around Bourton on the Water, Witney and Newbridge. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. Levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are falling slowly on the River Thames.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25), particularly in the Abingdon and Culham areas. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. We expect river levels to continue to fall but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation and operating weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but slowly falling on the Ginge Brook. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry.  We expect levels in the Brook to remain high over the next few days and to remain responsive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: The River Nene has been falling steadily today, Saturday 1st February. North Bank Road will be reopened once the Highways Authority have been able to inspect the road surface and carry out any necessary works to ensure the road is passable. There may be standing water in low lying areas and fields for several days.

items.message:

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

However, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25), particularly in areas close to the river in Calcutt, Lechlade, Castle Eaton and Kempsford. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. 

We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly.  Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Middle Nene has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are falling slowly on the River Thame. However, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25), particularly in the Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days and may rise as water moves down the catchment. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
The river level remains high at the Sherborne Lake gauge, and this may lead to flooding. No property flooding is expected. Locations most at risk are low lying land and roads near the upper River Yeo around Sherborne. All other rivers in the South East Somerset area are at their normal winter level, with no threat of flooding at this time.

Saturday, Sunday and Monday are forecast to be predominantly dry and settled. We are closely monitoring both rainfall and river levels, and staff are out checking rivers for blockages.

Please remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions, and be careful using low lying footpaths and bridges near watercourses.

This message will be updated by midday on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels continue to be high due to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
Following recent rainfall water levels are rising steadily.
This information is correct as of 15:15 Saturday 1st February. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 24 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.  
There are currently no issues on Welney or Earith causeway. 
We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 02/02/2025.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady on the Lower Colne following recent rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Flooding is affecting locations near the River Colne, Frays River, Wraysbury River and Poyle Channel, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Longford. No flooding to properties is expected. 
The next 5 days are forecast to be dry, so we expect river levels to slowly fall.
We are closely monitoring the situation and continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 5pm on Saturday 01/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Minimal rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Dikler from Condicote to Little Rissington
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high but stable on the River Dikler.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25), particularly around the confluence in Bourton on the Water. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 01/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly declining on the Chertsey Bourne following heavy rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 01/02/25. No rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels are expected to continue slowly declining over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels remain high after recent rainfall. The rest of the week is forecast to be mostly dry conditions which should allow river levels to start to reduce.  Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester may also be affected. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 02/02/2025.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
items.message: River levels remain high after recent rainfall. The rest of the week is forecast to be mostly dry conditions which should allow river levels to start to reduce. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Wyboston to the south of Brampton, including Duloe Brook, Hen Brook and Fox Brook. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 02/02/2025.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 4:30 PM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 01/02/25.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10am on 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from today, Saturday 1st February, and for at least the next 24hrs. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect, and tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth which is restricting the normal drainage of the Broads river system out to sea at low tide. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message tomorrow morning, Sunday 2nd February, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.12m and currently stable while it receives water cleared from the moor. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.23m and falling slowly.

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m.

The Parrett Relief Channel is open to help reduce river levels, and pumping is taking place at both Huish Episcopi and Westover pumping stations. Saturday, Sunday and Monday are forecast to be predominantly dry. We will continue pumping activities to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow during this settled period.

Staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on road closures. 

This message will be updated by midday on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:

Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Bristol Avon and Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. 

Further showers are forecast on Tuesday but are not expected to cause any further flooding.

We are clearing debris from weed screens and monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Please avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and keep up to date with the weather forecast for your area. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 11:00am on Sunday 02/02/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but areas vulnerable to high tides may still be at flood risk.    No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

Levels are expected to continue falling steadily through today, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25), particularly between Lechlade on Thames and Newbridge, and in the Eynsham area. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. We expect river levels to continue to fall, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: This alert has been removed due to river levels falling back below levels of concern. We are closely monitoring the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are falling slowly on the River Thames and its tributaries in the Oxford area. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is therefore likely, particularly in the New Botley area around the Bulstake Stream. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. We expect river levels to continue to fall, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation and operating weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message:
River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible today, Saturday 01/02/2025. Areas most at risk include Low Marishes. Levels remain high around Low Marishes. No further impactful rainfall is expected over the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, drive, or cycle through flood water.

This message will be updated by 9pm on Saturday, 01/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: West Somerset Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding. Weather conditions are expected to remain dry and settled through Saturday, with periods of light rain possible on Sunday. We expect river levels to continue falling and no further flooding is forecast at this time.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.85 mAOD at 16:45 on 01/02/25 and 4.60 mAOD at 04:45 on 02/02/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 264 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but stable on the Lower River Loddon following heavy rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, 01/02/25, especially in the Sindlesham Mill area. No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours. River levels are expected to start slowly declining over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation and if internal property flooding is forecast we will issue a flood warning. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Gribbin Head to Rame Head
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tide on Sunday 2nd February.

High water at Plymouth is at 08:17 on Sunday. However, conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.

On Sunday, up to force 5 south-easterly winds and wave heights of up to 1.4m are forecast to cause minor overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Locations particularly at risk include Fore Street, Town Quay, Albert Quay and Caffa Mill Car park at Fowey, Quay Street and Recreation ground at Lostwithiel, Polperro Harbour, Quay Road and The Quay at Looe and the B3247 at Seaton, alongside other exposed locations.

Coastal conditions should ease for Sunday evenings high tide. However, we will continue to monitor the situation and issue an update by midday on Sunday 2nd February.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; at Plymouth, the astronomical tide level is 2.42 mAOD but expect levels to be up to 200mm higher than published.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tide on Sunday 2nd February.

High water at Falmouth is at 07:44 on Sunday. However, conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.

On Sunday, up to force 5 south-easterly winds and wave heights of up to 1.4m are forecast to cause overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Locations particularly at risk include Cadgwith and Coverack, Porthallow, the tidal Helford Estuary, Maenporth and Swanpool, St.Mawes, East Portholland, Gorran Haven, Portmellon, Mevagissey, Pentewan and Par, alongside other exposed locations. 

Coastal conditions should ease for Sunday evenings high tide. However, we will continue to monitor the situation and issue an update by midday on Sunday 2nd February.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; at Falmouth, the astronomical tide level is 2.29 mAOD but expect levels to be up to 200mm higher than published.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: South Cornwall Coast, Tidal Fal Estuary

items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tide on Sunday 2nd February.

High water at Falmouth is at 07:44 on Sunday. However, conditions may apply two hours either side of the high tide. Times of high water will vary along the coast.

On Sunday, up to force 5 south-easterly winds and wave heights of up to 1.4m are forecast to cause overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations. Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas in Falmouth, Penryn, Flushing, Mylor Bridge, the A39 at Perranarworthal, Devoran, Calenick, Truro and the A390 at Tresillian, alongside other exposed locations.

Coastal conditions should ease for Sunday evenings high tide. However, we will continue to monitor the situation and issue an update by midday on Sunday 2nd February.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; at Falmouth, the astronomical tide level is 2.29 mAOD but expect levels to be up to 200mm higher than published.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
Higher than normal tides on Saturday and Sunday morning may lead to flooding. Highest tide level is expected to be at Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon at 11:15 AM on 01/02/2025 and 11:45 on 02/02/2025 Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.

We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tides during the evenings. We have closed flood gates and are monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Christchurch Harbour. The first forecast high water is at 11:15 AM on 01/02/2025 with a level of 1.25 mAODN with south easterly force 4 winds. The second forecast high water is at 11:45 AM on 02/02/2025 with a level of 1.27 mAODN with south easterly force 3 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)
This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected this afternoon, 01/02/25, at 5:30pm and is forecast to reach between 4.95 and 5.09 metres. The following high tide is expected tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, at 5:30am and is forecast to reach between 4.96 and 5.10 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks again and flood low lying land for both high tides. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 01/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected this afternoon, 01/02/25, at 5:30pm and is forecast to reach between 5.05 and 5.19 metres. The following high tide is expected at tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, at 5:30am, and is forecast to reach between 5.02 and 5.16 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks and flood low lying land for both high tides. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 01/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message:
Flooding is expected as a result of spring tides combined with flood water. Water levels will be at their highest between 11:00 and 12:00 this morning 01/02/25. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. A series of high tides is due over the next 2 days.  

Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary.  

Morning tide predicted peaks:- Gloucester 3.3m to 3.6m, 11:15 this morning, 01/02/25. Sandhurst 3.4m to 3.7m, 11:30 this morning, 01/02/25. Other gauges to remain below flooding threshold.  

Evening tide predicted peaks:- Gloucester 3.2m to 3.5m, 23:30 tonight, 01/02/25. Sandhurst 3.2m to 3.5m, 23:45 tonight, 01/02/25. Other gauges to remain below flooding threshold.  

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churnet and River Tean
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert, if necessary.    
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.28m. Current fluctuating levels are due to pumping activities and the influence of high tides. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m.

The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.97m and falling steadily. Cutts Road floods when this level is above 5.75m, and New Road when the level is above 6.18m. Please refer to https://www.somerset.gov.uk/roads-travel-and-parking/emergency-road-closure-gates for information on road closures in the area.

Pumping is taking place at Currymoor, Northmoor and Saltmoor pumping stations, and we will continue to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. The forecast for Saturday, Sunday and Monday is predominantly dry and settled.

The situation is being continually monitored, and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens.

This message will be updated by midday on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding the Tidal Fal Estuary
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: Flood Warning issued in error. Flood alert will be issued shortly.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent and rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to rise and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Levels are reactive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is expected over the next few days with upto 35mm expected to fall over 2 days, which could see levels continue to rise.

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 03:30 PM on 3/2/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are still high in response to recent rainfall and flooding of fields and roads is possible. Areas most at risk include: the Iwerne and the Pimperne Brook areas. Further rainfall is forecast in the next few days which could see levels rise across Cranborne Chase. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 04/02/2025.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wylye and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wylye, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Norton Ferris and Wilton.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 11:30 AM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Piddle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is no longer expected. 

River levels are high but falling on the lower reaches of the River Kennet following recent rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25). Areas most at risk are those around Theale, Burghfield and Calcot. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Loddon at the River Thames confluence at Twyford
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but are continuing to fall on the River Loddon. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today (01/02/25) especially in the Loddon Drive area of Wargrave, with flooding of roads possibly affecting access to properties.
No rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are falling along much of the Upper Kennet catchment.  However, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25), particularly in the Hungerford area. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are falling slowly on the Winterbourne Stream in Bagnor and the Lambourn in Newbury. However, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue today (01/02/25). The forecast over the coming days is currently dry.  We expect river levels to fall steadily over the next few days. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at Britford, Salisbury
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Lower Road and Church Lane.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Don't put yourself or others at risk.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon from Salisbury to Ringwood
items.message:
Recent rainfall has resulted in river levels rising. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around south of the A36 at Salisbury to Blashford in Ringwood including Charlton All Saints, Breamore, Fordingbridge and Bickton.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Please do not drive through floodwater as bow waves may affect adjacent properties. Don't put yourself or others at risk. 

This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly falling on the River Thames following heavy rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today (01/02/25) in the Shiplake area. No rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels are expected to continue slowly declining over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Mapledurham to Sonning
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are falling slowly on the River Thames. However, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected, particularly in areas around Sonning. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. We expect river levels to continue dropping slowly over the coming days. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation and operating weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Pangbourne to Purley
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are falling slowly on the River Thames. However, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected today, particularly in areas around Whitchurch, Pangbourne, Mapledurham and Purley. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation and operating weirs on the Thames to manage flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels on the Thames are slowly falling. However, the flooding of roads and low lying land remains possible today (01/02/25). We expect levels will  continue to fall over the coming days.  Levels are also high but continue to drop slowly on the Mill Brook in Blewbury. The forecast over the coming days is currently dry.  

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Do not drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but slowly declining on the River Thames following heavy rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today (01/02/25) in the Hurley area. No rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels are declining slowly and this is expected to continue over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but starting to decline on the River Thames following heavy rainfall earlier in the week. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Datchet to Shepperton Green
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but stable on the River Thames following heavy rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 01/02/25, in the Egham, Penton Hook, and Chertsey areas. No rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to start slowly declining over the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 02/02/25, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon and tributaries
items.message:
High river levels may lead to flooding. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Hampshire Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 10:30 AM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Thames Ditton Island

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected this evening, 01/02/25, at 6:00pm and is forecast to reach between 5.54 and 5.68 metres. The following high tide is expected tomorrow morning 02/02/25 at 6:00am and is forecast to reach between 5.54 and 5.68 metres. Therefore, the river may get close to overtopping banks again at both high tides. We expect river levels to start slowly declining over the next few days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 01/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Iwerne
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster. The groundwater level at the Iwerne Hill Farm borehole has risen to 110m, and is expected to rise due to further rainfall over the next few days, with up to 44 mm expected to fall over 2 days.
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.


Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 29/01/2025.

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are starting to fall, but remain high as a result of recent rainfall on the Colne Brook. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Flooding will continue to affect locations near the Colne Brook and Lower Colne, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Colnbrook Village, Poyle and Albany Park. No flooding to properties is expected.
The next 5 days are forecast to be dry, so we expect river levels to continue to fall.
We are closely monitoring the situation and continue to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 5pm on Saturday 01/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high, further rainfall is expected over the next few days which could result in levels rising further. Levels are still reactive to further rainfall. Areas at risk include; areas around the Till and the Wylye Valley. Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 04/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the South Wiltshire Downs - The Dene
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Hindon. The groundwater level at the Terraces borehole has risen to 116m, and is expected to continue to rise due to recent rainfall. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 03:30 PM on 04/02/2025.

items.description: Middle Hampshire Avon at The Close and West Harnham, Salisbury
items.message:
High river levels are causing flooding in the area. Areas most at risk include West Walk, The Close, De Vaux Place, St Nicholas Road, Harnham Road, Watersmeet Road and St Marys Road. We are closely monitoring river levels.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 02/02/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen slightly following recent rainfall, but are broadly stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, levels remain above normal and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater. Low-lying land, roads and cellars may be at risk of flooding. 

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, on 4 February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley. However, they remain above normal and communities may be affected by groundwater. Low-lying land, roads and cellars may be at risk of flooding. 

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, on 4 February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and rising. In the last week, over half a months rain (53mm) was recorded at Bishops Sutton. During this time, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 25cm. At Old Alresford, the level has risen by 8cm. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, a small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks in Old Alresford will be struggling to operate effectively. From today 27/01/2025 until Friday 31/01/2025, further rain is expected. It is possible that this rain could be heavy, bringing up to 45mm across these 5 days. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising until at least mid-February. It is possible that internal ground floor flooding impacts could affect isolated properties in Old Alresford during February if further heavy rain continues to affect the area. We continue to monitor the groundwater levels and weather forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 5 February 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the autumn and early winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high autumn and early winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 5 February 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are continuing to rise slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton following rainfall over recent weeks. Groundwater levels are above normal and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to continue rising slowly and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, cellars and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, on 4 February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hayling Island
items.message: Updated Flood Alert due to the ongoing condition of the shingle beach at South Hayling, which has been severely impacted by high energy waves. The early morning tide at 01:45 on Sunday (02/02/2025) may cause flooding. Winds are light Southerly Force 4. The total forecast tide is 4.86 metres Chart Datum (2.13 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Tide levels are not overly high, this is a precautionary alert for 1 hour either side of high water, as waves may affect the beach at South Hayling. This could lead to some overtopping or spray affecting beach front gardens at Bembridge Drive, Meath Close, The Strand and Southwood Road. The Sunday lunchtime tide at 13:45 on 02/02/2025 is also forecast at 4.86m Chart Datum (2.13 mAOD). Similar impacts to the Sunday morning tide are possible. We are liaising with the local authority response teams over the condition of the beach. Prom clearance and maintenance works for Eastoke will start on Monday (03/02/2025) and will last approximately 5 days. Avoid South Hayling seafront at high tide. We will update this message daily by 16:00, until Tuesday 04/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hursley are high and rising quickly. In the last week, over half a months rain (53mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne. During this time, the level at Hursley has risen by 74cm. The Dolphin Inn pub and properties in South End Close are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Sewerage system impacts in the village are expected to be occurring. From today 27/01/2025 until Friday 31/01/2025, further rain is expected to affect Hampshire. There is a possibility that this rain could be heavy, bringing up to 45mm across these 5 days. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising until at least mid-February. It is possible that most of the village will experience cellar flooding and sewerage system impacts before this weekend. Internal ground floor flooding impacts are possible during February. We continue to monitor the groundwater levels and weather forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover are high and rising. In the last week, over half a months rain (43mm) has been recorded at Andover. During this time, the level at Clanville has risen by 18cm. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw and Hatherden. Groundwater is affecting the sewerage network in Penton Mewsey and the main road into Penton Grafton is flooded. From today 27/01/2025 until Friday 31/01/2025, further rain is expected to affect Hampshire. There is a possibility that this rain could be heavy, bringing up to 45mm across these 5 days. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising through much of February. From early February, it is possible that groundwater emergence into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton may occur, as well as sewerage impacts in Appleshaw and Hatherden, and cellar flooding in Penton Grafton. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 03/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high and continue to rise. In the last week, over half a months rain (50mm) has been recorded at Overton. During this time, the level at Oakley has risen by 31cm. The River Test is flowing through Deane and Ashe. Groundwater will be affecting the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. From Thursday 30/01/2025, properties in Deane are expected to be affected by cellar flooding. From today 27/01/2025 until Friday 31/01/2025, further rain is expected to affect Hampshire. There is a possibility that this rain could be heavy, bringing up to 45mm across these 5 days. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising throughout February. It is possible that the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) will need to be closed towards the end of February. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 03/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising steadily at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon following rainfall over recent months. Groundwater levels are above normal and have now reached a level at which communities may be affected by groundwater flooding. We expect levels to continue rising slowly over the coming weeks and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land, cellars and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, on 4 February 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Till
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain are high and are forecast to rise further early next week. Areas that could be affected include: Tilshead, Orcheston, Shrewton and Berwick St James. The groundwater level at the Tilshead borehole has risen to 97.7m, and is expected to rise further due to predicted rainfall, with up to 44mm expected to fall over 2 days.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures over the weekend and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 29/01/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Chitterne Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Chitterne. The groundwater level at Chitterne Down borehole has risen to 101.5m, and is expected to continue to rise due to previous rainfall, with further rainfall expected over the next few days.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3:30 PM on 04/02/2025.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Wylye Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Kingston Deverill, Monkton Deverill, Hill Deverill, Longbridge Deverill, Crockerton, Norton Bavant, Heytesbury, Corton, Upton Lovell, Boyton, Sherrington, Stockton and Bapton. The groundwater level at the Tilshead borehole has risen to 107.8m, and is expected to rise further this evening over the 108m threshold due to previous rainfall.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 03:30 PM on 04/02/2025.

items.description: River Mimram in Hertfordshire
items.message: Flooding is affecting low lying land and roads close to the River Mimram, due to persistent rainfall in December and January, leading to high groundwater levels. Flooding is currently affecting the Fulling Mill Lane, Singlers Marsh, and Codicote Road areas in Welwyn. No property flooding is expected at this time. River levels in other areas remain below levels of concern. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next 5 days. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are continuing to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 5pm on Saturday 01/02/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Wylye Valley at Warminster
items.message:
Groundwater levels in Salisbury Plain remain high. Areas that could be affected include: the Wylye Valley at Warminster. The groundwater level at the Tilshead VP 10 borehole has risen to 108.5m, and is expected to continue to rise due to previous rainfall.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas.

Flooding of roads is expected, take particular care when driving, both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. Roads may have become damaged by floodwater.

Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 03:30 PM on 04/02/2025.
